newsitem.title: UK: LME copper premium dwindles, but caution over Sept.
newsitem.headline: LME copper premium dwindles, but caution over Sept.

text.p: Copper premiums have fallen on the London Metal Exchange (LME) as highly-visible warehouse inventories swell, but there is caution over September dates.

This month copper stocks have risen without interruption in the LME's warehouses, while the cash/threes backwardation has more than halved. But traders are unwilling to call "time' on LME tightness, as August is a slow month industrially and total copper stocks are still very low.
"As we get to the end of August we will see premiums rise and prices will go higher," said one senior trader.
Since the end of July LME warehouses stocks have grown from 224,100 tonnes to the current 266,000 tonnes, cutting the cash premium over three months from $110 to the current $35/$40.
Analysts were unsure whether the trend reflected fundamental oversupply -- long anticipated after high prices throughout the 1990s encouraged a whole host of low-cost new production.
Or, analysts said, copper may have been lent to the LME during the summer slowdown to take advantage of high premiums.
Meanwhile, end-users looking to book requirements after the seasonal shutdowns said there was reasonable availability for the remainder of this month. But September is a different story.
"It is early days yet, but a lot of people are starting to look around, and there is not that much there," the trader said.
On the LME there are several likely tight dates in early September all relating to the massive sell-off seen on the market in June when the extent of the Sumitomo Corp scandal unravelled.

September 5/6 is one hurdle, as this is three months after Sumitomo said it found evidence of unauthorised trading by its former head trader Yasuo Hamanaka. In a $500 price-slide, over one million tonnes of copper was cleared on the LME.

Another sensitive area will be September 12 through to the September "third Wednesday" date (September 18), as this will be three months after Sumitomo announced its $1.8 billion of unauthorised losses, prompting another heavy sell-off.
"There was a lot of short-selling then. Some of those (shorts) will cover, but a lot may be rolled forward. If so, we will have a backwardation for much longer," another trader said.

Outside the LME, the stock picture shows total inventories falling, with levels of some 805,000 tonnes equating to between 3.6 and four weeks consumption, dangerously close to a historically critical level of 3.5 weeks.
There have been reports of up to 100,000 tonnes of copper being held in China's bonded warehouses in Shanghai with the threat of these being sold on to the market.
But traders and analysts are doubtful of this occurring as China is expected to be a net importer of copper metal and ore during the final quarter of 1996.
And the copper from the new projects and expansions in North and South America and the Far East may take some time to show up in statistics.

"With some of the SX-EW (solvent extraction-electrowon) and start-up metal probably off-grade, it is likely that a lot of the new metal will not be put on warrant, but used to alleviate the likely shortage in scrap," analyst William Adams of LME trader Rudolf Wolff and Co said.
Although the metal is in the system, sentiment will focus on the visible inventory on the LME, with prices likely to react accordingly, others said.
"There is tightness in September, which could continue through Ocober and even into November," the senior trader said.
